title.narrative: Strengthened Accountability Program II: Diakonia Zambia

description.narrative:
Diakonia arbetar i Zambia med att stärka medborgares förståelse för deras roll i, och hur de kan bidra till, den politiska, ekonomiska och sociala utvecklingen i landet. Diakonia arbetar också för att öka förståelsen för vikten av jämställdhet och jämlikhet, samt att öka kvinnors deltagande i beslutsfattande.
Under de senaste åren har Diakonia implementerat SAP-I programmet (finansierat av Sida), vars syfte har varit att se till att medborgare får ökad tillgång till resurser. Diakonia föreslår nu att implementera en andra fas av projektet; SAP-II. Det nya programmet kommer att bygga på lärdomar av vad som fungerade/fungerade mindre bra under SAP-I, och en uppdaterad kontextanalys av Zambia. Diakonia ansöker om finansiering från Sida till ett värde av SEK 41 400 000 för perioden 2018–2021, för att implementera SAP-II. Ambassaden har allokerat SEK 1 000 000 för att genomföra en oberoende utvärdering vid programmets slut (2021).
SAP-II kommer att täcka ett större geografiskt område än SAP-I. Programmet kommer också att dubbla antalet samarbetspartner (från fem tio). Syftet är fortsatt att bidra till att medborgare för ökade möjligheter att påverka beslutsfattande, kräva transparens och ansvarsutkrävande, och bidra till en mer rättvis naturresursallokering. Diakonias långsiktiga mål med programmet är att förbättra livskvalitén för samhällen (framförallt för kvinnor, ungdomar, fattiga och mest utsatta) i naturresursrika områden i Zambia.

Diakonia is an international development organization made of two Swedish churches. The head office is located in Sweden. In Zambia, Diakonia works to increase Rights Holders (RHs) understanding of their role in political, social and economic development processes, the importance of achieving gender equality and increasing women’s participation.
Over the past years, Diakonia has been implementing their SAP-I programme (supported by the Embassy of Sweden) aimed to ensure that Right Holders (RHs) have increased access to resources through engagement with corporate and public sectors. Diakonia now proposes to implement the SAP-Phase II (SAP-II) based on the achievements, lessons learned, best practices from the SAP-I and the current context in Zambia. Hence, Diakonia has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 41,400,000 for the period 2018-2021 to implement the SAP-II. The Embassy has also allocated a SEK1,000,000.00 for an independent end of program evaluation to be undertaken in 2021.
The SAP-II will see the expansion of the programme to new geographical areas while also scaling up coverage in additional sites in the previous targeted districts. The programme will continue to address challenges of vulnerable communities in predominantly rural areas by strengthening RHs participation in enhancing equality, transparency and accountability in national resource allocation. Diakonia´s overall goal and expected long-term change with the SAP-II is to improve quality of life of communities (especially, women, youth, the poor and most vulnerable groups) in natural resource rich, rural and peri-urban areas of Zambia. The overall programme objective is to empower RHs to hold duty bearers accountable for equitable access and distribution of national resources.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer

title.narrative: Strengthened Accountability Program II: Diakonia Zambia
Strengthened Accountability Program II: Diakonia Zambia

description.narrative: Overall, 2018 (June – December) was dedicated to starting up the new program, SAP-II. Particularly, the year was used for setting up the partnerships and the operating structures for the projects implementation. This was successful as agreements were signed with 10 implementing partners during the period under review, partner inception workshops were held, and capacity assessments were concluded on all partners informing the risk assessment and the capacity building plans. However, the start-up phase faced big delays linked to that Diakonia´s own capacity was limited. Particularly, contracts with partners were only signed in November, and funds were only disbursements in December, delaying implementation of many planned activities. From a total of 16 assessed organizations, 14 organizations were selected and categorized as either an implementing or resource partner. However, contracts were only signed with the 10 selected as implementing. Agreements with the 4 selected resource partners were only formalized in 2019. Prior to the award of grants, the implementing partners were further divided into “activity based partners” and “project based partners”. The two categories specify how funds are disbursed, the level of monitoring, and capacity building needed. Assessments considered the organizations board composition, effectiveness of internal controls and liquidity in respect to statutory backlogs, recent audits, etc. Through the appraisal of Diakonia´s proposal and initial dialogue with the Embassy, Gender, Environment and Conflict Sensitivity were identified as critical areas which need to be mainstreamed in the entire program. These areas will be critical parts of the capacity building plans (these are individual action plans drawn from the assessment of each partner). Some concrete activities (discussed during the Annual Review Meeting) that Diakonia may put into the workplans are availing Diakonia´s Gender Toolkit to partners to review their results frameworks, supporting partners in developing environment policies, and training in Do No Harm and availing Diakonia´s Conflict Mainstreaming Toolkit. In SAP-I, there were some challenges with coordination between partners working on attaining the same results, and the Embassy has followed-up with Diakonia how they are managing this in the new programme. As a result of the dialogue issue, Diakonia have considered and elaborated on the added value which comes from the Programme Coordination Committee in contributing to effective coordination. However, during the next field trip with Diakonia, the Embassy should pay attention to how partners on the ground work together and that this has improved from the previous program. One of Diakonia´s main roles in the SAP-II is being "the coordinator", so this really should/needs to work well for the programme to deliver on the intended results. During the period under review, Diakonia initiated an innovative approach for the baseline study. Rather than hiring a consultant to do the work, Diakonia and implementing partners own the baseline process together as the partners are the ones collecting the baseline data and writing the document, together with Diakonia. The study is, however, delayed, as a result of the partner agreements and award of grants being delayed. As of now, Diakonia have completed the data collection exercise, targeting 4000 participants. Also, Diakonia and partners had completed the analysis of both quantitative and qualitative data and are currently finalizing the report. The Embassy has requested, as per the agreement, that Diakonia shall submit an updated results framework once the baseline is complete, as a pre-condition for the next disbursement. The Embassy is also providing support (through the procured NIRAS RBM consultant) in finalizing the baseline survey and the results framework. Several of the challenges faced during 2018 were linked to that Diakonia had insufficient internal capacity due to lean staffing level. The office only operated with four full-time staff. To respond to this, Diakonia have now recruited two new staff: a second Programme Officer and a Grant and Compliance Officer. Yet, staff turn-over (both within Diakonia and the programme partners) continues to be a key risk that may jeopardize and delay programme activities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
